summary: This is a forwarded email chain from July 9, 2019, discussing a Vanity Fair article about President Trump's politicization of the Department of Justice. The article expresses concern about political pressure on the DOJ, particularly regarding the Southern District of New York's investigations into Trump-related matters and the Jeffrey Epstein case.

persons.name: Chris Smith
persons.context: Author of the Vanity Fair article discussing Trump's politicization of the DOJ.

persons.name: Sally Yates
persons.context: Former acting attorney general who was fired by Trump in 2017 after refusing to defend the travel ban; cited as warning about Trump's politicization of the DOJ.

persons.name: William Barr
persons.context: Trump's attorney general who is described as protective of Trump and involved in replacing the DOJ legal team handling the census citizenship question case.

persons.name: Sarah Fabian
persons.role: Senior Attorney, DOJ Office of Immigration Litigation
persons.context: DOJ attorney who argued in court that it was 'safe and sanitary' for immigrant children to go without soap or toothbrushes.

persons.name: Mike Pence
persons.context: Described as throwing Sarah Fabian 'under the bus' when her argument became controversial.

persons.name: Thomas Hotelier
persons.context: Wrote analysis stating the census citizenship question would disadvantage Democrats and advantage Republicans.

persons.name: Joshua Gardner
persons.context: DOJ attorney with 16 years experience who expressed confusion about Trump's position on the census citizenship question after learning about it via Twitter.

persons.name: Emily Pierce
persons.context: Former senior adviser in the Justice Department under Barack Obama who comments on Trump's politicization of the DOJ.

persons.name: Joe Arpaio
persons.context: Former sheriff pardoned by Trump after being convicted of criminal contempt of court.

persons.name: Matthew Miller
persons.context: Former DOJ spokesman under President Obama who comments on Trump's politicization of the department.

persons.name: Mimi Rocah
persons.role: Former Chief, SDNY Organized Crime Unit
persons.context: Former SDNY prosecutor who states the SDNY presents the greatest ongoing legal threat to Trump and expresses concern about political interference.

persons.name: Matthew Whitaker
persons.context: Barr's predecessor who was reportedly asked by Trump about putting a loyalist in charge of SDNY investigations; denied this under oath.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Billionaire charged by the SDNY with sex trafficking; mentioned as an example of the SDNY's high-profile cases that might face political interference.

persons.name: Nicholas Biase
persons.role: Public Affairs, U.S. Attorney's Office SDNY
persons.context: Public affairs officer for the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York; appears in the email signature.

persons.name: Barack Obama
persons.context: Former president mentioned in relation to DOJ officials who served under his administration.

persons.name: Stormy Daniels
persons.context: Mentioned in relation to SDNY investigation into Trump's role in paying her off.

connections.description: Trump appointed Barr as Attorney General; Barr is described as protective of Trump and involved in replacing DOJ legal teams to advance Trump's political agenda.
Trump fired Yates as acting attorney general after she refused to defend the travel ban executive order.
Trump reportedly asked Whitaker about putting a loyalist in charge of SDNY investigations, though Whitaker denied this under oath.
Implied connection through the article's concern that Trump might intercede if SDNY moves to indict Epstein or Trump's associates.
Barr succeeded Whitaker as Attorney General.
Rocah, as former SDNY organized crime chief, comments on the SDNY's case against Epstein as an example of high-profile investigations that might face political interference.

events.title: Trump Travel Ban Executive Order
events.description: President Trump signed an executive order banning refugees and immigrants from seven majority-Muslim countries, leading to lawsuits and Sally Yates' refusal to defend it.

events.title: Supreme Court Census Ruling
events.description: Supreme Court ruled against adding a citizenship question to the 2020 census, but Trump continued to push for it, causing confusion among DOJ lawyers.

events.title: DOJ Legal Team Replacement
events.description: Trump and Barr replaced the DOJ legal team handling the census citizenship question case, seen as an unprecedented political move.

events.title: Trump Inquiry About SDNY Loyalist
events.description: Report that Trump asked acting AG Matthew Whitaker about putting a loyalist in charge of SDNY investigations into Trump-related matters.

events.title: SDNY Charges Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Southern District of New York charged billionaire Jeffrey Epstein with sex trafficking, mentioned as a high-profile case that might face political interference.

keyFacts: The document expresses concern that President Trump has politicized the Department of Justice and may interfere with the Southern District of New York's investigations.
The SDNY is investigating Trump-related matters including the Trump Organization, payments to Stormy Daniels, Deutsche Bank loans, and Trump's inaugural committee finances.
The SDNY had recently charged Jeffrey Epstein with sex trafficking, raising concerns about potential political interference in that case.
Trump reportedly asked former acting AG Matthew Whitaker about putting a loyalist in charge of SDNY investigations, though Whitaker denied this under oath.
Career DOJ attorneys were troubled by Trump's pardon of Joe Arpaio and his attempts to influence the census citizenship question case.
